title: Wednesday, 24th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
PM

Hi

PM

My fault

PM

a few (cough) moving parts to this morning

11:03 am
PM

Welcome to ML

PM

One of those moving parts inovlves this...

PM

Which can serve as our pic of the day

11:05 am
PM

PM

PM

11:05 am

PM

PM

But you can follow the links in that post and reach your own conclusions

11:07 am
BE

That makes it all sound clandestine, Paul.

BE

Which is perhaps unhelpful when a thousand tinfoil-hatted nutters are all over Twitter shouting about stuff.

BE

All I'd note is that the short interest on Wirecard looks like this:

11:07 am
BE

PM

Oh i switch Twitter off when such matters come up

BE

That's 25% of Wirecard out on loan.

11:09 am
BE

And while today's report is certainly an interesting read, its gist shouldn't be too unfamiliar with any investor who's been listening to all sides of the argument over the past few years.

PM

INdeed

PM

Let's move on

11:10 am
PM

We should be used to the queasy feeling that goes with moving markets, but so be it

undefined
PM

So tin hat back on for sure

11:10 am
PM

Generally

PM

Footsie off 1.3% currently

PM

Miners. Miners!

11:11 am
BE

Those miners sure do go up and down, don't they! That's my added-value observation for the day.

PM

hahaha

BE

So the Saudi oil minister came out of his palace yesterday and knocked a few dollars off Brent by saying no production cuts.

11:12 am
BE

And when Brent heads back below $30, he'll come out of his palace again and hint of production cuts.

BE

It's a neat wee game, and it's working. More or less.

PM

Full text is here: http://fingfx.thom...%20CERA%20WEEK.pdf

11:12 am
BE

Keep Brent just below the $35-ish breakeven that US shale can operate at.

BE

But keep it above the $30ish the Saudis need to buy a bunch of weaponry.

BE

The result is ..............

11:13 am
BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 337.00, down 8.35 (-2.42%), High: 344.05, Low: 336.05, Volume: 12.48m
Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 1,529, down 42.94 (-2.73%), High: 1,563, Low: 1,522, Volume: 2.77m
BE

And in terms of secondary effects .......

11:13 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 120.00, down 9.45 (-7.30%), High: 127.00, Low: 119.05, Volume: 27.86m
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 691.80, down 55.1 (-7.38%), High: 728.00, Low: 686.80, Volume: 6.65m
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 422.35, down 30.75 (-6.79%), High: 450.15, Low: 415.45, Volume: 3.76m
11:14 am
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 1,913, down 75.5 (-3.80%), High: 1,975, Low: 1,898, Volume: 1.96m
BE

(@Whatsgoinngonhelp: yes, it's a startup. This is their first bit of published research.)

BE

I could go on.

11:15 am
BE

But instead, here's Citi to go on.

BE

The UK metals and mining sector has outperformed the UK market in both relative and absolute terms. The sector has benefited from a weaker USD and clients confidence around M1/M2 growth in China. On a bottom up level, BHBP and Rio have joined Glencore and Anglo in cutting their dividends with the former moving to a payout ratio. The market has surprisingly in our view, welcomed this move, however in our opinion the mining sector is now trading at a yield discount relative to the market and with lower growth options our fear is share prices will be pushed down until we see a market rate of return.

BE

The major issue we have at this point is that the major miners are not making their cost of capital and therefore don’t have a sustainable business (to fund growth and dividends). Moreover the executives have not changed their strategies and are still reliant on the expectations that demand is going to increase and bail them out as highlighted in Hope is Not a Strategy. From a bottom up perspective we think there is limited self-help drivers from here, with the exception of Glencore on debt restructuring.

11:15 am
BE

The miners have arguably already run ahead of the macro conditions. Earnings momentum remains negative on spot versus consensus with the exception of Rio Tinto so broadly we need commodity prices to rally from here to drive the sector in our view.

BE

Our excess monetary supply chart highlights a trend reversal since Jan 16 as the PBoC injected over RMB1.7tn in Jan vs RMB100.1bn in Dec. However as per our economists strong lending supports growth stabilization in the short term, but expects medium term growth risks to persist (Jan Money Data: Surprisingly High Bank Loans). Our economist continue to think the USD will trade weak, until the point at which the US real rates begin to recover which is probably the spring, however growth remains uneven in US$ terms.

BE

In conclusion the risk reward is balanced given the run up in share prices and we move to a Neutral stance on the sector from Bullish.

11:16 am
BE

Check this out for a psychedelic graph.

BE

BE

Or if that's too complicated, try Figure 2.

11:17 am
BE

BE

Thanks, Citi.

undefined
11:17 am
PM

That's a fantastic graph

PM

I wish more people would use primary colours

PM

Brightens up the day

11:19 am
BE

Before moving on from the sector, should also stop over at BHP Billiton

PM

(Whatsgoinngonhelp -- see comments on the bottom of the post)

PM

Why in particular on BHP?

11:20 am
BE

Because we all said yesterday's dividend cut was expected, then it happened, and the shares are still 15% lower.

BE

Basically, seems management's plan has underwhelmed.

BE

And we now have to value BHP ex growth.

11:22 am
BE

Here's JP Morgan doing exactly that.

BE

BHP’s H1’16 results reinforced key components of our UW thesis. In order to
defend its balance sheet the interim dividend was cut ~75% (JPMe 50% cut),
the progressive dividend policy was abandoned and capex was cut ~$3bn
across FY'16-17. Yet on forward curve commodity prices, ND/EBITDA
remains elevated at ~2.5x in CY'16-17E. Under the new payout ratio policy,
we calculate an unattractive ~2% CY’17E dividend yield vs ~4% for RIO. We
forecast BHP faces -0.5% CAGR volume decline CY’15-20E, -6% in
Petroleum due to its more rapid depletion, vs +2.5% growth for RIO. Despite
these detractions BHP’s 8.5x CY’16E EV/EBITDA is at a ~40% premium to
RIO (6.0x) and we believe BHP’s equity should de-rate relative to peers. We
adjust our PT to £6.00/sh (from £5.50/sh) to reflect lower net debt, but retain it
as our Analyst Focus List UW.

BE

 H1’16 financials weak: $6.0bn underlying EBITDA was 6% below JPMe,
due to higher costs at Escondida, Coal and in Iron Ore. Underlying earnings
of just $412m compared to $730m JPMe. $25.9bn net debt (30% gearing)
was lower than $26.8bn JPMe due to a $0.8bn working capital release and
tax and capex benefits relative to forecasts.

11:23 am
BE

 Payout ratio dividend policy, capex guidance cut by ~$3bn: In what we
regard as a sensible move, BHP has moved to a dividend policy of paying
out greater than 50% of underlying profits, which corresponds well to historical total
cash returns. At forward prices, and with the 16c interim dividend, we
calculate a CY’16E yield of just 1%. Capex has been lowered by ~$3bn
across FY’16-17E to $7bn/5bn (~$1bn below JPMe). Management is being
restructured along regional lines, but cost savings were not quantified.

BE

Capital adequacy addressed, but leverage still elevated: Abandoning the
$6.6bn pa progressive dividend, plus deeper capex cuts, protects BHP’s
investment grade rating, in our view, eliminating the risk of equity issuance
at this stage. Yet at spot or fwd curve (oil ~$40/bbl, FeO $43/t) prices we
calculate CY’16-17 ND/EBITDA at ~2.5x, vs RIO’s ~1.5x.

BE

BHP set to shrink: We forecast group copper equivalent production will be
15% lower in 2020 than 2015. We believe reserve replacement challenges
exist in Petroleum, where we forecast a -6% CAGR for 2015-20E. Organic
growth options such as Spence’s $2.2bn, 200kt pa copper expansion, or
M&A, are likely to be constrained by BHP’s more leveraged balance sheet.
 Valuation premium unjustified: On spot commodity prices we calculate
BHP’s CY’16E EBITDA at $11.0bn vs RIO’s $12.6bn. Yet BHP’s $94bn
EV is 26% larger, which is anomalous in our view. Both companies have a
~10% CY’16 EBITDA sensitivity to a 10% change in iron ore prices,
therefore we believe BHP is a more compelling way to express downside
risk to iron ore prices (JPM’s $40/t 2016E iron ore price is 22% below spot).
Our PT increases 9% on account of lower net debt, but we remain UW.

11:24 am
PM

okay, the yield has shrunk to a prospective 1%.

PM

You can see why they're leery

PM

So are we saying BHP is no longer a blue chip?

11:25 am
PM

Can't be considered a reliable, stable investment

PM

That's where we've arrived

BE

We're saying, I guess, that BHP is currently a debt story.

11:26 am
PM

Underminer -- makes the point on Aussie retail investors

BE

Hm. There must be at least a dozen of those. Anyway, let's push on.

undefined
11:27 am
BE

Some antagonism on the right that we're not talking about shale pumps.

Weir Group PLC (WEIR:LSE): Last: 868.50, down 33 (-3.66%), High: 972.50, Low: 867.50, Volume: 1.63m
BE

FY results. Orders are rubbish, unsurprisingly.

11:28 am
BE

Margins aren't as bad as feared but H2 still misses consensus.

BE

2016 guidance is poor -- which shouldn't really be a surprise.

BE

Jefferies says it was hoping for better though.

11:29 am
BE

Weir's FY15 results were mixed, in our view, but this was always going to be
the case, and the market's focus has always been on the FY16 outlook and
the net debt position. Both of these appear worse than we had previously
thought, which leads us to reiterate our caution. With the US upstream business
currently at break-even and order intake in Minerals falling aggressively in
4Q15 (after a uninspiring 3Q15), the group is not out of the woods yet. U/P.

BE

Results commentary: Weir this morning announced mixed FY15 results, as we/the
market had expected. Sales of £1,918m were c4% light of company-compiled consensus
(£2,004m), PBTA of £220m was c2% below consensus of £223m (with lower central costs
and interest charges helping) although EPS of 78.4p was c4% ahead of consensus of 75.7p
(due, in part, to a better-than-expected minority interest number). The FY15 DPS of 44.0p
was unchanged yoy. Year-end net debt of £825m was c8% below consensus expectations
- working capital inflows were solid, but a touch light versus our forecasts, and there was
a large FX impact - which is a concern, particularly given on-going strength in the US$,
and year-end Net Debt:EBITDA was 2.5x. Additionally, we note that there was £367m of
exceptional charges incurred in the year, which really was an 'exceptional' number.

BE

Order Intake: Worryingly, order intake continued to deteriorate throughout the year, with
FY15 order intake declines of 27% yoy, on an OCC, basis across the group (we note that this
was -31% in 3Q15 and -34% in 4Q).

11:29 am
BE

Minerals division: The division continues to face numerous headwinds, falling commodity
prices, reduced safety stock levels and postponement of scheduled maintenance. FY15 OI
was -9% on a LFL basis, and we note 4Q15 OI was -19% on a LFL basis, (with OE -41% and
aftermarket -8%), which was on top of weak prior year comparatives of 15% LFL declines,
and a trend that deteriorated as the year progressed. As anticipated, EBITA margins decreased
by 100bps to 19.2% (FY14:20.2%) although mgmt. comment that gross margins increased
by 120bps on a LFL basis as a result of a more favourable mix and the benefits of procurement
and restructuring initiatives, which more than outweighed continued pricing pressure, On
outlook, mgmt. guide for "slightly lower constant currency revenues with operating margins
broadly stable in 2016."
Oil & Gas division: As expected, this was clearly a very difficult end market, however we
are surprised that mgmt. comment that the North American upstream business is "currently
operating at around break-even level", with double digit pricing pressure in North America.
FY15 OI was -48% on a LFL basis and 4Q15 OI for the division was -55%, with OE -62% and
aftermarket -53%. EBITA margins decreased 1280bps to 10.0% reflecting the impact of lower
volumes, negative operating leverage and pricing pressure. On the outlook, mgmt. guide
for further significant "reduction in constant currency revenues" and with operating margins
impacted by additional "negative operating leverage".
Power & Industrial: The Power & Industrial division delivered a sensible performance
with FY15 OI down 11% on a LFL basis, (with OE down 20% and aftermarket down 2%),
sales of -5% and EBITA margins that increased by 130bps to 7.2%, clearly benefitting from
the cost saving actions taken. Mgmt. guide for “broadly flat constant currency revenues and
operating margins” in 2016.

BE

Summary: These are not great results, but the market was already expecting this, in our
view. The outlook remains very difficult, and we expect consensus downgrades to come
through in Oil & Gas, and we remain concerned about Minerals (despite its consistency)
and net debt (despite mgmt's focus). We see nothing to get excited by in these results (and
plenty to be concerned by) and reiterate our Underperform rating.

BE

(@RuminationsOn: yes, I'd forgotten about the frackog. Thanks for the reminder.)

11:31 am
BE

And Stifel.

BE

Weir reported full year results this morning. As ever, the group has come out fighting, and the headlines of the results statement are initially reassuring - strong positive cashflow, revenue stability in the important Minerals aftermarket (AM) business, cost savings coming through (£110m in 2015) and more in the pipeline (£40m incremental savings targeted for 2016).But the further down the statement you read, we think it gets worse. There are large new charges (£365m; a million for each day of the year!), Oil and Gas in US upstream markets is said to be down to breakeven levels of performance, and Minerals AM sales may be stable, but the order trend is still weaker (-8% LFL in Q4, only marginally better than the -10% reported in Q3, which the group strongly denied was a trend). 2015 numbers overall were below both our expectations and consensus (headline op prof £259m bs our £270m) and 2016 consensus will likely need to be adjusted down again, especially for Oil and Gas. Weir continues to do a good job of controlling the things it can control, but the benefits of these efforts are being entirely overwhelmed by the collapse in its markets.

undefined
11:33 am
BE

Meanwhile, on the opposite side, Petrofac.

PM

Top of the 250 board

PM

Sorry we're late

11:33 am
BE

Cash pretty good! Net debt better! Load of writedowns, though.

BE

Laggan Tormore and IES are written down again, resulting in a bottom line net loss of $349m.

BE

Above that, through, management seems to have a handle on things. Finally.

11:35 am
PM

Is that not a rash statement Bryce?

BE

Well, the thing with Petrofac is that it has a very long order book.

BE

So it should be reasonably defensive, relative to other oil services companies.

11:36 am
BE

Unfortunately, management has a tendency to do stilly stuff like order a gigantic boat for deepwater installations.

BE

And project management has been a bit of an issue, at times.

BE

So a lot of time is spent cleaning up what we can euphemistically call legacy issues.

11:37 am
BE

Here's Canaccord to summarise how that's going.

BE

FY results reported this morning are solid, with net profit before the Laggan-Tormore
(LT) losses of $440mn broadly in-line with analyst expectations and a flat dividend, as
previously flagged. There are a number of write-downs and impairments, as expected,
reflecting the impact of a weaker oil price on the E&P portfolio. Importantly, cash
collection towards the year-end has been strong, and there appears to have been some
delay in payments to suppliers, resulting in strong year-end net debt of just $686mn,
more than $300mn better than we had expected. At $20.7bn, order backlog remains
one of the strongest in the sector and (as we have written earlier) more or less covers
profits throughout 2016 and 2017.

BE

Reducing net debt is critical to Petrofac's investment case: for what should be an
asset-light business, the company remains relatively indebted, and the cash position is
tighter than it appears because of the large ongoing need for cash to back performance
guarantees. However, $300mn better is significantly better.
There remains the possibility of further losses on LT: as disclosed in the results, the yearend
includes a provision of $48mn related to LT. However, the project is handed over to
the client, and we believe the scope for further loss is limited.
The Greater Stella Area project is progressing in-line with previous guidance, with
sailaway of the FPF1 targeted for 2Q and first production this summer. This is the most
positive we have yet seen this much-delayed project and is broadly similar to recent
comments from Ithaca.
Progress on the core Middle East project portfolio remains robust, with customers still
making new investments, and although the outlook statement is cautious it contains the
key statement that "embedded margins [in the backlog are] consistent with guidance" -
which is critical, and positive.
Petrofac remains in dispute with the shipyard building its offshore construction vessel
(the boat): we continue expect settlement of this issue later this year.
Lastly, the company has launched a $90mn cost reduction initiative, much in-fashion
and (arguably) unnecessary given its large backlog for execution this year & next.

11:38 am
BE

The issues we wrote about earlier this month remain: earnings beyond next year are
heavily dependent on continued investment from Middle Eastern customers, it is almost
solely dependent for its cash flow on upstream oil & gas, and its reinvestment track
record is mixed at best. We see little in the short term that management can do to
address these.

BE

We remain HOLDers with a price target based on a blend of a slowdown scenario value
(c.500p) and the base case (c.950p).

BE

And Nomura.

11:39 am
BE

Petrofac reported net profit at USD 440m (in line with guidance of
USD 435m). The company reported adjusted EBITDA at USD 792m and
reported EBITDA (ie, post Laggan Tormore charge) of USD 312m. Petrofac
reported a USD 168m loss in the second half all related to Laggan Tormore,
and the total charge after tax in FY 2015 was USD 431m. Net profit before
exceptional items and post Laggan Tormore was USD9m. Key takeaways
that underpin our Buy case:
1) Significant improvement in net debt, which stood at USD 686m (June
2015: USD 1bn), reflecting strong cash collection (we estimate USD 600m
reduction in credit receivables) during 4Q15 and an improvement in working
capital and execution.
2) Full-year dividend maintained at 65.8 cents per share (2014: 65.8
cents).
3) The company has maintained 2016 net income guidance at
USD 450m (NOMe: USD 492m). Assuming USD 45/bbl, IES should
generate a modest loss in 2016, and we model USD -12m (NOMe oil price
forecast USD 40/bbl).
4) Backlog at USD 20.7bn drives sector-leading revenue visibility in
2016/17, driven by strong project momentum in Middle East. In our
report EU OFS: Global capex outlook - 2016E spend down 20% y-o-y, we
highlighted that Middle East ECOM is poised to grow further on renewed
contract momentum in 2016, led by continued growth in GCC capex as
OPEC seeks higher production capacity. Recently, Petrofac was awarded
the Fadhili contract by Saudi Aramco and a number of contract extensions,
including a USD 100m one-year extension with South Oil Company for
support on its Iraq Crude Oil Expansion Project.

BE

Christyan Malek's the analyst there.

undefined
11:39 am
PM

BT

PM

Isnt there this ofcom report tomorrow

BE

Yep.

11:40 am
PM

Are they going to get told to spin off Openreach?

BE

Nope.

PM

Hmm

11:40 am
PM

Thought you'd say that

PM

Some one needs to put pressure on them tho

PM

I'm still waiting for fibre on my road

11:41 am
PM

And I don't live on some moor

PM

I have some Haitong on BT actually

BE

Oh, John Kardis is it? Sure.

11:41 am
PM

Yeah

PM

Tomorrow Ofcom will unveil initial conclusions of its Strategic Review of Digital Communications (SRDC). We remain confident the authority will not call for Openreach to be separated from BT. So below we highlight other big issues we expect will feature tomorrow.

Because we think it is relevant and useful, we also convey information to have emerged from the ongoing inquiry by the Culture, Media and Sport Committee of MPs into the rollout of fibre in areas where state subsidies are necessary. BT (BT/A LN, 460p, BUY, FV 570p) is our top pick.

PM

He's enthusiastic

11:42 am
PM

BT critics say Openreach has underinvested over the years. First, Ofcom obliges Openreach to deliver c.5% efficiencies every year. So every year Openreach has to deliver more for the same money. Second, in all state-funded schemes BT has to date committed to spend £440m capex, but also £470m opex. For one, this means capex is not the sole indicator of network investment.

PM

Hmm -- if they can't deliver proper fast internet in SE10 i think its pretty clear they have underinvested

PM

Some companies say they stand ready to invest with Openreach in rolling out fibre. But the government's Broadband Delivery UK (BDUK) scheme has been a very large test case in co-investment with Openreach already.

According to the BDUK CEO (December 2015), “I think nine originally started the process to compete for the [BDUK] framework contract and there were four or five bidding for a number of the early local body contracts, they were serious players. These were not just small companies. In some cases they were large companies or large partnerships. They were credible players, but they were unable to match BT for scale or cost.”

The reasons why we think co-investment with Openreach does not happen are (i) Openreach is obliged to provide access to all of its network on an equal basis to all parties, and (ii) the payback periods are very long (15 years in the case of BDUK contracts).

11:43 am
PM

Critics imply BT has been gifted government subsidies. In December 2015, the BDUK CEO said the following to MPs: “The contracts we have with BT across all of these [BDUK] projects are one of the best contracts I have come across in my 30 years of working in the commercial sector. It is an extremely strong contract. It puts all the risk on to BT. We have complete visibility of all their costs and we literally only pay for what we receive. We have an incredibly tight value for money process that we wrap around with our governance at BDUK to make sure we are getting value for money on behalf of the taxpayer.”

He also said “the advantage of going with BT for phase 1 and phase 2 [of the BDUK program] is they have allowed us to deploy a very large volume of premises passed in a short period of time. As I said, we are up to 3.3m premises passed in two years. That is a phenomenal rate. We have been running at 40,000 premises a week for the best part of two years now, certainly since I arrived in April 2014. Some of the smaller companies have taken up to five years just to get 10,000 to 20,000 premises during that period of time in total.”

Lastly he also noted BDUK had “a clean bill of health from the National Audit Office”.

PM

Actually, have a big block to finish off

PM

Ofcom must clarify if Openreach ROCE

WACC is a problem for the authority or not. Ofcom estimated that, in the nine years to FY14, BT’s regulated returns exceeded WACC by £4bn in total. The regulator believes c.2/3rds of this gap is because of Ofcom’s policy choices and the rest is due to BT responding to its (regulator-approved) incentive to outperform charge controls. But debate and press article headlines about BT’s past ROCE have combined (i) ROCE on services which were subject to price controls with (ii) ROCE on services which, after full industry consultations, were deliberately subject to looser cost orientation obligation, or even just an obligation to report returns in regulatory accounts.

Ofcom must decide if it prefers active or passive regulatory remedies. Active remedies require Openreach to wholesale fully functional services like leased lines. Passive remedies require it to wholesale access to physical network parts like ducts or dark fibre (i.e. fibre without electronics on either end to provide a connectivity service). Ofcom said the “acid test” of any shift from active to passive remedies is whether the authority can then withdraw active remedies. Oddly Ofcom proposes to impose both active and passive remedies in the business connectivity market…

Ofcom may make it harder for SKY (SKY LN, 1,019p, SELL, FV 875p) to defend share against rivals like BT. Ofcom said it will consider “competition concerns within the pay TV sector in relation to Sky’s position” in the SRDC. Also “any strategic approach to sustainable competition in digital communications needs also to consider whether the potential for competition problems in content provision may also affect competition in the provision of telecoms services”. We think Ofcom will look to impose a ‘Gaining Provider Led’ customer switching process for triple-play services, which will reduce SKY’s ability to retain customers (when they call to say they are leaving).

Ofcom may repeat its opposition to Three consolidating Britain’s mobile market from four to three network operators. In its ‘Discussion document’ (October 2015), Ofcom said “the Three/O2 merger would lead to a more concentrated mobile market” and “to date, our approach to competition in mobile is that UK consumers are likely to benefit from better services and lower prices if there are at least four credible national wholesalers of mobile services [network operators]”.

11:43 am
BE

Hm. I've never quire understood why broadband speed is such a political hot-button issue.

BE

Sure, it's nice when YouTube doesn't buffer. But it's not requiring of the same attention as, for example, providing drinkable tap water.

BE

(Related: I have Youtube that doesn't buffer, but don't have drinkable tap water.)

11:44 am
PM

( danger )

BE

Anyway, the weekend press pre-dropped the Ofcom report. There will be a few concessions with regards access and suchlike but BT will get to preserve its monopoly.

PM

(TheLeggie: SE10 8HB, if someone's watching)

11:46 am
BE

And Vodafone will remain, strategically speaking, a busted flush.

PM

(rw42 -- there you go!)

BE

.... Unless and until it can figure out a way to make Malone happy.

11:46 am
Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 211.52, down 2.38 (-1.11%), High: 215.00, Low: 210.80, Volume: 13.16m
undefined
BE

Guess we should mention yesterday afternoon's news.

11:47 am
London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE:LSE): Last: 2,578, down 52 (-1.98%), High: 2,668, Low: 2,578, Volume: 1.25m
BE

German takeover of LSE, no matter how much "merger of equals" stuff they throw into the press release.

BE

The tone of yesterday's conversations was that it's pretty much a done deal.

11:49 am
BE

After about a month of work.

BE

Which LSE might've been bounced into by interest from elsewhere.

PM

having personally written the Germans and London and/ or London and Nasdaq to merge story about five times, Im not holding my breath here

11:50 am
BE

Yeah, I know. It's a hardy perennial of a story.

PM

The Germans are offering a premium of circa 10%, yeah?

PM

Since when does that clinch a deal?

11:51 am
BE

When you have a motivated seller, I guess.

BE

In terms of counter .... no idea. But the suggestion of HKEX coming in seems not to be gaining a lot of traction.

PM

Well HKEx could have done it at any time in the past 6/8 yeas, but havent

11:52 am
BE

And are now at the very start of a three-year strategy plan, announced last month.

BE

HKEX is looking into China now, not outwards towards Europe. So goes the theory anyway.

BE

Singapore's too wee.

11:53 am
BE

And while one of the mainland China exchanges might come in, I guess, we get the usual problem of regulation.

BE

Look at the US pressure against the Chinese bid for Chicago.

BE

http://www.foxnews...-investigated.html

11:55 am
PM

Blimey, missed that

PM

(And, er, I didn't know Chicago had a stock exchange)

BE

(Chicago's one of the dullest cities on the planet. Of course it has a stock exchange.)

11:56 am
BE

So .... counterbidders might plausibly come from the States. But that's more likely to be a scenario that bumped LSE into jumping into bed with the Germans than would bump it back out again.

BE

Here's Credit Suisse, one of the few brokers that hasn't suddenly gone restricted this morning.

BE

Compelling cost synergy potential: While the exchange ratio has been
confirmed, there are still no details of targeted cost or revenue synergies.
Assuming cost synergies equivalent to 15% of combined entity costs, in line
with recent exchange consolidation, implies c.£280m of pre-tax expense
synergies based on our pro-forma cost base of c.£1.9bn. If we apportion
45.6% to LSE shareholders and capitalize it at LSE's pre-deal multiple with a
tax rate of 26%, then this would produce about £1.5bn of added value or
440p per LSE share (vs. our current fundamental target price of 2,900p).

creation potential from revenue synergies resulting from opportunities such

offering trading in related derivatives on Eurex; 3) enhanced attractions as

(e.g. clearing, custody & collateral management).

BE

This potential combination would create a €26.3bn/US$29.8bn entity
The combined exchange would be the 3rd–largest globally using current market values.
We would view a merger of equals between the DB1 & LSE positively. For the most
part, the two firms operate complementary businesses (see Figure 1) which provides a
strong strategic rationale to the deal. We see the greatest opportunity for the business
combination related to the potential margining benefits clients would receive from their
interest rate derivative positions at LCH.Clearnet (OTC) and EUREX Clearing (Exchangetraded).
The deal could be 9% Accretive in 2020E
Assuming a deal between LSE and DB1 is completed at year-end under the terms
specified yesterday, we believe the combined entity would enjoy 9% accretion by 2020.
Over the past 10 years, the average expense synergies in exchange deals have been
26% of the acquired firm's cost base (in this case we use LSE as the 'acquired' firm as it
is the smaller of the two entities). We think the opportunity for this deal would be
slightly lower than the average at 25% of LSE's 2016 expense base, or 11% of the
combined expense bases of LSE & DB1.
How to invest around the potential deal
We continue to rate DB1 a Buy and LSE a Neutral. In a scenario where the deal is not
completed (either due to LSE/DB1 not coming to a final agreement or if the deal is not
granted regulatory approval), we would prefer exposure to DB1 as a stand-alone entity.
While there is the potential for 3rd-party bids to be placed for LSE we continue to rate
the firm Neutral. While both BME and Euronext enjoyed 3-5% increases to their share
price yesterday following this news, we do not forecast them to be beneficiaries of
consolidation. We continue to rate BME and Euronext Sell.

eOne shares have been weak in the last 12m (down c.-50%) which we believe
has been driven by several factors including a) a reduced 2016 film slate,
b) one-off effects that have reduced cash flow, c) the company’s £200m rights
issue to gain control of Peppa Pig and d) the company’s recent £285m
refinancing (at 6.875%). However, as highlighted before, we expect FY16
results (end March 16) to be the tipping point for cash conversion (JPMe 55%
in FY16, vs. 38% in FY15) and remain buyers into the upcoming 9M15
trading statement (likely first week of March). With the shares now trading on
c.6.5x cal. 2016E P/E, we see risk-reward as very attractive given several
growth opportunities from TV production, the Mark Gordon company and
rolling out the Family business (Peppa Pig and other) globally. Our
2016E/2017E adj. EPS estimates of 19.8p/20.6p are above BBG consensus at
19.6p/20.1p.

 We forecast improving FCF metrics for FY16. Rightly or wrongly
eOne’s ability to generate cash remains a key focus area for investors.
Given that the company is continuing its growth strategy, we expect interim
production financing to continue increasing (JPMe 2016/2017/2018
£100m/£135m/£170m). However, we calculate that FY2016 results may
provide an inflexion point in terms of cash generation with operating CF
growing faster than investment spend (with the cash generative Family
business gaining further importance in the Group context). We calculate
improving FCF going forward (JPMe £75m/£97m/£112m for
2016E/2017E/2018E for adj FCF).
 Our estimates may prove too conservative. We calculate 2016E-2018E
adjusted Group EBITDA CAGR of +15% with TV Production (+24%) and
Family (+17%) as key growth drivers. Further upside potential comes from
the Mark Gordon business which could produce hit series (eg similar to
MGC’s Grey’s Anatomy, Criminal Minds), performing materially better
than we currently anticipate.
 Our 2016E/2017E EPS estimates change by -4.5%/-2.4% largely due to
higher interest in 16E and marginally lower EBITDA margins in 17E.
